{{Infobox musical artist | name = Mose Vinson | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = | alias = | birth_date = 1917
[[Holly Springs, Mississippi]], [[United States]] | death_date = November 2002 (aged 85)
[[Memphis, Tennessee]], United States | origin = | instrument = [[Piano]], [[Human voice|vocals]] | genre = [[Boogie-woogie]], [[blues]], [[jazz]] | occupation = [[Pianist]], [[singing|singer]] | years_active = 1930s–2002 | label = [[Sun Records]], [[Bear Family Records]], Wolf Records | associated_acts = [[James Cotton]] | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Mose Vinson''' (June 2 or August 7, 1917 – November 16, 2002){{cite book|authors=LeBlanc, Eric S; Eagle, Bob L.|title=Blues: A Regional Experience|pages=224-457|publisher=Praeger|date=May 2013|edition=1st|isbn=978-0313344237|quote=The authors give a birthdate of June 2, 1917 "near Holly Springs," Mississippi, but also note that according to the SSDI records, his birthdate was listed as August 7, 1917. Accordingly, they note that the date of death is taken from the Tennessee Death Records Index}} was an [[United States|American]] [[boogie-woogie]], [[blues]] and [[jazz]] [[pianist]] and [[singing|singer]]. His best known [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]]s were "Blues With A Feeling" and "Sweet Root Man". Over his lengthy career, Vinson worked with various [[musician]]s including [[Booker T. Laury]] and [[James Cotton]].{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/2002b.html?referer=www.clickfind.com.au |title=The Dead Rock Stars Club 2002 July to December |publisher=Thedeadrockstarsclub.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}} ==Biography== Vinson was born in [[Holly Springs, Mississippi|Holly Springs]], [[Mississippi]]. He taught himself how to play the [[piano]] as a child. In his teenage years, Vinson started playing his own style of barrelhouse boogie-woogie in local [[juke joint]]s in Mississippi and Tennessee, incorporating both blues and jazz in his repertoire. In 1932, following a chance meeting with [[Sunnyland Slim]], Vinson relocated from Mississippi to [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]], [[Tennessee]].{{cite news |url=http://www.memphisflyer.com/CityBeat/archives/2002/08/01/local-beat |title=Local Beat |author=Lisle, Andria |publisher=''[[Memphis Flyer]]'' |accessdate=October 14, 2010}} In the 1930s and 1940s, Vinson continued to play at local juke house and rural community parties. By the early 1950s, Vinson found employment as a custodian at the Taylor Boarding Home, where artists often stayed whilst recording next door at [[Sun Records]] [[recording studio|studios]]. In the studios, [[Sam Phillips]] occasionally requested that Vinson accompany musicians. These included [[James Cotton]] on "Cotton Crop Blues" (1954), and Jimmy DeBerry on the latter's "Take a Little Chance".{{cite book | first= Steve | last= Cheseborough | year= 2009 | title= Blues Traveling - The Holy Sites of Delta Blues | edition= 3rd | publisher= Upress | location= United States | isbn= 978-1-60473-124-8 | pages= 34 & 41}} Phillips also allowed Vinson to record some tracks of his own, although these were not released until the 1980s. Vinson recorded two versions of "[[Forty-Four (song)|Forty-Four]]", one retitled "Worry You Off My Mind", and the other as "My Love Has Gone" (also known as "Come See Me"). [[Session musician]]s on these recordings included [[Walter Horton]], [[Joe Hill Louis]] and [[Joe Willie Wilkins]]. After a period of lesser musical activity, by the early 1980s, the [[Center for Southern Folklore]] had enlisted Vinson to perform at various cultural events, and at local schools. He became a regular at the Center, where he played and taught for twenty years. In 1990, his contribution towards the [[album]], ''Memphis Piano Blues Today'', was recorded at his home. In 1997, his first full-length [[Compact disc|CD]] [[compilation album]] was released via the Center.{{cite web|url=http://www.bealestreet.com/wordpress/beale-street-walk-of-fame |title=Beale Street Brass Note Walk of Fame |publisher=Bealestreet.com |date= |accessdate=October 14, 2010}} Declining health, however, stopped him playing not long before his death. Mose Vinson died of [[diabetes mellitus|diabetes]], in November 2002 in Memphis, at the age of 85. In 2007, the Memphis Music and Heritage Festival was dedicated to his memory. ==Date confusion== Historically, there has been some confusion over both the birth and death dates for Vinson. [[Allmusic]] quotes August 7, 1917 and November 30, 2002;{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=mose-vinson-p34727/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Mose Vinson |author=Dahl, Bill |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=October 14, 2010}} whilst the ''[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music]]'' cites August 7, 1917 and November 16, 2002;{{cite web |url=http://www.oldies.com/artist-biography/Mose-Vinson-Booker-T-Laury.html|title=Mose Vinson biography |author=''[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music]]''|publisher=Oldies.com |accessdate=October 14, 2010}} yet another on-line source specialising in death details quotes June 2, 1917 and November 23, 2002. The information contained in ''Blues: A Regional Experience'' by Eric S. Leblanc (author), Bob L. Eagle (contributor), published in 2013, is deemed to be the most reliable and definitive to date.{{By whom|date=April 2014}} ==Quotation== {{cquote|I just play my own style, I never did practice anyone else's style.}} ==Discography== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Album title !Record label !Year of release |- |''Memphis Piano Blues Today'' |Wolf Records |1990 |- |''Mose Vinson: Piano Man'' |Center for Southern Folklore |1997 |}{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/memphis-piano-blues-today-mw0000086331 |title=Memphis Piano Blues Today - Booker T. Laury,Mose Vinson | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=1990-10-04 |accessdate=2014-01-27}}{{cite web|url=http://www.southernfolklore.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=98&Itemid=348#Vinson |title=Center for Southern Folklore |publisher=Southernfolklore.com |date= |accessdate=October 14, 2010}} ==See also== *[[List of Delta blues musicians]] *[[List of Country blues musicians]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Allmusic|artist/mose-vinson-p34727}} *{{IMDb name|2392793}} *{{Worldcat id|lccn-no98-7066}} {{Authority control|VIAF=21754621}} {{Persondata | NAME = Vinson, Mose | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = [[United States|American]] [[boogie-woogie]], [[blues]] and [[jazz]] pianist and singer | DATE OF BIRTH = 1917 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Holly Springs, Mississippi]], United States | DATE OF DEATH = November 2002 | PLACE OF DEATH = [[Memphis, Tennessee]], United States }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Vinson, Mose}} [[Category:1917 births]] [[Category:2002 deaths]] [[Category:American blues pianists]] [[Category:American jazz pianists]] [[Category:American male singers]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:Boogie-woogie pianists]] [[Category:Blues musicians from Mississippi]] [[Category:Country blues musicians]] [[Category:Delta blues musicians]] [[Category:Memphis blues musicians]] [[Category:Deaths from diabetes]]
